org.freezedry.persistence

Class PersistenceEngine

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.freezedry.persistence.PersistenceEngine

  • public class PersistenceEngine
extends java.lang.Object
    Creates a semantic model of the specified Object, and creates a specified Object form a specified semantic model. The semantic model is a tree that holds the information about each element (field) in a InfoNode. The InfoNode information is a complete set of information needed to persist and reconstruct the specified Object.

    The PersistenceEngine allows you to specify NodeBuilders that are responsible for converting an object into the semantic model, and a semantic model back into an object. By default, a set of node builders are created and added to the PersistenceEngine at construction. However, through the addNodeBuilder(Class, NodeBuilder) method, you can specify which node builder to use for which class. For example, for and instance of the PersistenceEngine, engine you can map a Map to a MapNodeBuilder, so that all Map objects use the MapNodeBuilder to convert between the semantic model and an object, by

    engine.addNodeBuilder( Map.class, new MapNodeBuilder() );

    Importantly, in this case, the PersistenceEngine will use the MapNodeBuilder for all objects that implement Map. That means that a LinkedHashMap will also use MapNodeBuilder. Suppose you want to have the LinkedHashMap used a different NodeBuilder, say LinkedMapNodeBuilder (which doesn't exist, but you could write one), then you would perform the mapping as above:

    engine.addNodeBuilder( LinkedHashMap.class, new LinkedMapNodeBuilder() );

    And now, HashMap would use the MapNodeBuilder, but LinkedHashMap would use the LinkedMapNodeBuilder.

    To customize the behavior of any NodeBuilder you write, you may also define annotations that works in conjunction with your NodeBuilder. For example, the PersistCollection annotation works in conjunction with the CollectionNodeBuilder. The field annotation argument elementPersistName allows you to define the name that is used to persist each element, and the elementType allows you to define the type (Class) of each element. Or as another example, the PersistDateAs annotation allows you to define the format with which a date is persisted. By default, class constants (i.e. static final fields) are not persisted. Use the setPersistClassConstants(boolean) to change the default behavior. Note that class constants are not set when reconstructing the class from the persisted form. In other words, the class constants always take their value from the class source code value. When parsing the semantic model, this class will attempt to instantiate an object of the specified class by calling the constructor with the smallest number of arguments. If a no-argument constructor exists, then that is what will be called. Constructors that have arguments will be passed null objects, and then the fields will be set reflectively through the Field.set(Object, Object) method. This means that if the constructor performs checks against null, you will have a problem. (TODO allow passing default values to the constructor so that the instantiation passes its checks).

    See Also:
    InfoNode, NodeBuilder, PersistenceWriter, PersistenceReader, Persist

      • addNodeBuilder

        public NodeBuilder addNodeBuilder(java.lang.Class<?> clazz,
                         NodeBuilder builder)
        Adds a NodeBuilder to be used for generating InfoNodes for the specified Class
        Parameters:
        clazz - The Class of the object to persist and, therefore, for which to generate a node
        builder - The NodeBuilder used to generate InfoNodes for the specified Class
        Returns:
        The NodeBuilder that used to be associated with the specified Class; or null if no NodeBuilder was previously associated with the specified Class

      • containsNodeBuilder

        public boolean containsNodeBuilder(java.lang.Class<?> clazz)
        Finds the NodeBuilder associated with the class. If the specified class doesn't have a info node builder, then it searches for the closest parent class (inheritance) and returns true. In this case, it adds an entry to the info node builders map for the specified class associating it with the returned info node builder (performance speed-up for subsequent calls).
        Parameters:
        clazz - The class for which to find a info node builder
        Returns:
        the true if a info node builder was found; false otherwise

        Parameters:

        fieldName - The field name to check for a NodeBuilder annotation.
        Returns:
        true if the specified field name of the specified Class has a NodeBuilder annotation; false otherwise.

In this case, it adds an entry to the info node builders map for the specified class associating it with the returned info node builder (performance speed-up for subsequent calls).
        Parameters:
        clazz - The class for which to find a info node builder
        Returns:
        the NodeBuilder associated with the class

      • setGeneralArrayNodeBuilder

        public void setGeneralArrayNodeBuilder(ArrayNodeBuilder builder)
        Sets the default NodeBuilder used for arrays (String[], int[], Object[], etc) for objects for which a specific NodeBuilder hasn't been specified. You can add a specific array NodeBuilder to using addNodeBuilder(Class, NodeBuilder) method. For example:

        builder.addNodeBuilder( String[].class, new ArrayNodeBuilder() )

        maps all String[] objects to use the ArrayNodeBuilder.

        Parameters:
        builder - The default NodeBuilder to use for arrays for which a specific NodeBuilder hasn't been specified.

        public final InfoNode createSemanticModel(java.lang.Object object)
        Creates a semantic model of the specified Object. The semantic model is a tree that holds the information about each element (field) in a InfoNode. The InfoNode information is a complete set of information needed to persist and reconstruct the specified Object.
        Parameters:
        object - The object which to convert into a semantic model
        Returns:
        The root InfoNode of the tree representing the semantic model
        See Also:

      • createNode

        public final InfoNode createNode(java.lang.Class<?> containingClass,
                  java.lang.Object object,
                  java.lang.String fieldName)
        Creates a InfoNode for the specified Object, recursively, calling either addNodes(InfoNode, Object) or itself to construct InfoNodes and add them to the tree.
        Parameters:
        object - The object for which to create the node
        fieldName - The name of the field for which to create the node
        Returns:
        the top-level InfoNode for the object

      • parseSemanticModel

        public java.lang.Object parseSemanticModel(java.lang.Class<?> clazz,
                                  InfoNode rootNode)
        Parses the semantic model (a.k.a. content tree) represented by the InfoNode tree hanging off the specified root InfoNode. The Class of the returned object is the more specific of the specified Class and the Class that may be held in the root InfoNode. The InfoNodes don't require all the information in each node to be complete. At a minimum it needs the field name (or the persist name if that is the same as the field name) and for leaf nodes, the value of the node. The PersistenceEngine will use reflection to fill in missing information. However there are limits to what can be obtained by reflection. For example, if the field is a List, then the actual concrete Class type must be available somehow.
        Parameters:
        clazz - The specified Class of the object to create
        rootNode - The root InfoNode representing the semantic model
        Returns:
        the object represented by the semantic model

      • instantiate

        private java.lang.Object instantiate(java.lang.Class<?> clazz,

      • createObject

        public java.lang.Object createObject(java.lang.Class<?> containingClass,
                            java.lang.Class<?> clazz,
                            InfoNode currentNode)
        Creates and returns the object represented by the specified InfoNode and Class. The method chooses the most specific type (i.e. farthest down on the inheritance hierarchy) found in the InfoNode or the Class. The specified InfoNode doesn't need to hold the type information, if such information is not available.
        Parameters:
        clazz - The Class type of the object to create (unless the one found in the InfoNode is more specific).
        currentNode - The InfoNode containing information about the object to be created
        Returns:
        The newly minted object
